1.brief: to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
the last or end, hence, the future; also posterity
a day (as the warm hours), whether literal (from sunrise to sunset, or from one sunset to the next), or figurative (a space of time defined by an associated term), (often used adverb)
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
a mountain or range of hills (sometimes used figuratively)
a house (in the greatest variation of applications, especially family, etc.)
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God

properly, to be erect (i.e. stand perpendicular); hence (causatively) to set up, in a great variety of applications, whether literal (establish, fix, prepare, apply), or figurative (appoint, render sure, proper or prosperous)
the head (as most easily shaken), whether literal or figurative (in many applications, of place, time, rank, itc.)
a mountain or range of hills (sometimes used figuratively)
to lift, in a great variety of applications, literal and figurative, absolute and relative

he (she or it); only expressed when emphatic or without a verb; also (intensively) self, or (especially with the article) the same; sometimes (as demonstrative) this or that; occasionally (instead of copula) as or are
to sparkle, i.e. (figuratively) be cheerful; hence (from the sheen of a running stream) to flow, i.e. (figuratively) assemble
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock

a foreign nation; hence, a Gentile; also (figuratively) a troop of animals, or a flight of locusts
abundant (in quantity, size, age, number, rank, quality)
to say (used with great latitude)
to walk (literally or figuratively); causatively, to carry (in various senses)
to ascend, intransitively (be high) or actively (mount); used in a great variety of senses, primary and secondary, literal and figurative
near, with or among; often in general, to

to walk (literally or figuratively); causatively, to carry (in various senses)

to go (causatively, bring) out, in a great variety of applications, literally and figuratively, direct and proxim.

between (repeated before each noun, often with other particles); also as a conjunction, either...or
a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock
abundant (in quantity, size, age, number, rank, quality)
to be right (i.e. correct); reciprocal, to argue; causatively, to decide, justify or convict
a foreign nation; hence, a Gentile; also (figuratively) a troop of animals, or a flight of locusts
powerful (specifically, a paw); by implication, numerous
as far (or long, or much) as, whether of space (even unto) or time (during, while, until) or degree (equally with)
remote, literally or figuratively, of place or time; specifically, precious; often used adverbially (with preposition)

the bottom (as depressed); only adverbially, below (often with prepositional prefix underneath), in lieu of, etc.
